bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, September 17, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] thanks Russell for sending him a translation of an article by Stevenel about the spirochetosis observed in the Ivory Coast.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, September 17, 1923
div1.opener:
File I. H. B.
Africa
/LC
Badin Hospital,
Badin, N. C.,
September 17, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I want to thank you for the translation of Stevenel's article
on the spirochetosis observed on the Upper Ivory Coast (Gulf of Gui-
nea).

While his histories are not given very fully. I would have
been inclined to regard yellow fever as a not improbable diagnosis.I
am inclined to doubt if anyone trained solely in the Americas can be
depended on for the differential diagnosis of yellow fever from some of
the spirochetal diseases reported from West Africa simply from clinical
history. He might not even if he saw the cases I wonder is it possible that the spirochete found is L. ic-
teroides, though one does not like to suggest the presence of aegypti
when the reporter failed to find them.
By the way is 20 spirochetes in one field a “small number?”

I hope and expect to be able to return to Washington about the
end of the month and shall be extremely glad to see you any time after
my return when you happen to be in Washington.
